entries.content: Start the call by confirming it's still an okay time to chat for a couple minutes.
My goal on this call isn't necessarily to sell you.
Frame the call goal as seeing if a further conversation makes sense.
If it does make sense, cool. If it doesn't make sense, totally fine as well.
entries.notes: Offers an easy opt-out, builds trust.

entries.content: Set expectations by stating you'll be asking questions to understand their situation.
Is that okay with you?
entries.notes: Asks permission for the proposed call structure.

entries.content: You must earn the right to ask questions.
entries.notes: Build context and rapport before deep discovery.

entries.content: Earn the right to ask questions by briefly stating the call's purpose and structure upfront.
Use a concise 10-second opener: State why you're calling, who you help, and why you thought it might be worth chatting specifically with them.
Earn the right to pitch. Don't pitch until you truly understand the problem.
Earn the right to pitch by asking questions and confirming you understand their needs before presenting a solution.
The more questions you ask, the better you understand the problem, leading to a more effective pitch.
Asking questions serves two purposes: gathering information and building trust by showing you care.
Don't be afraid to ask follow-up questions to dig deeper into a response.
Use silence effectively after asking a question; allow the prospect time to think and respond fully.
Confirm your understanding of their challenge before offering a solution.
So, if I understand correctly, the main issue is X?
entries.notes: Used to confirm understanding before transitioning.

entries.content: Transition from discovery to pitch by summarizing their problem and briefly introducing how your solution addresses it.
Based on what you've told me, it sounds like [summarize problem]. We help companies like yours address this by [briefly intro solution]. Would you be open to hearing how?
Maintain control of the conversation flow by guiding it with questions, not by dictating.
Act as a consultant or doctor; diagnose the problem thoroughly before prescribing a solution.
If a prospect gives a short answer, prompt them to elaborate with questions like 'Can you tell me more about that?' or 'What does that look like specifically?'
Listen actively to understand, not just to wait for your turn to speak.
Use reflective listening: Briefly paraphrase what you heard to show you were paying attention.
So, it sounds like X is a big priority for you right now.
If an objection is raised during discovery, acknowledge it but pivot back to understanding the full picture before addressing the objection directly.
Clearly frame the proposed next step at the end of the call.
If this makes sense, the next step would be a quick demo to show you how it works.
Confirm the prospect's commitment to the proposed next step.
Does that sound like a good plan?
End the call on a positive and appreciative note, regardless of the outcome.
Thanks for your time, I appreciate you sharing that with me.
Follow up promptly as promised after the call.
Maintain a confident but not pushy tone throughout the conversation.
Be genuinely curious about the prospect's business and challenges.
entries.notes: Authentic curiosity aids discovery and rapport.
